text.sentence: Hi Mike,
How are you?
How is everything going?
Is your internship over or are you still there? How did your work go?
I was at SIGIR last week and probably had most intellectually satisfying one week of my PhD.
Met some great people and had some great discussions.
Needless to say, discussions there were much more useful than with our "advisor" in past three years.
Even though the discussions will not help me solve problems I want to address but still, people tried to understand what I was saying and gave some really good suggestions.
I also feel kind of depressed given our miserable state.
Mitraji is coming to Almaden next week as a self invited visitor.
I asked him if we can visit some of his friends in search companies in valley to see if we can get some data.
He said, "Sure, who do you like to meet?" I was like, "Okay, let us try to meet Lary Page and Sergey Brin".
I mean WTF? I don't know who your friends are. I asked him if he knows anyone who works in related areas and then, as usual, no reply.
And here at IBM, these people are doing jugaad pe jugaad....they are like an ass's asshole. No chance of a paper whatsoever.
Forget the paper, no chance of any useful work :P
Totally frustrated and want to go back to India :( :( :( :) :) ;)
It's ok.
Just one more week left, then I'm done. :-) :-) :-)
I don't think the work was any good, but well, at least I got some money. :P :D
Nice to hear about your SIGIR experience. :-) :-) :-)
Yes, it is really those kind of people you want to network with, not like Mitra ji. :P :D
Don't worry about Mitra ji's friends.
He has none. :P :D
Unfortunate, but true. :P
And don't worry about internship work, either.
Usually it's all jugaad, nothing else. :P :P
Don't be frustrated.
Go and visit different places if you can. :-) :-) :-) :-)
The only way to end this impasse is to do Masters here and apply to other places (e.g., under Bruce Croft).
Now you have a very good chance that you'll be accepted.
Then only you can get a solution.
But the problem is it will take 4 more years, so it is a life-turning decision I feel somewhat shaky to make.
